thread.title: Bernardi gives Turnbull a colossal headache
thread.title_full: Bernardi gives Turnbull a colossal headache

title: Bernardi gives Turnbull a colossal headache
text:
Share on Twitter 
THE political right is set to splinter further with Senator Cory Bernardi expected to quit the Liberals tomorrow. 
This would make it harder for the Government to manage the Senate, and would add to the clutter of minor parties vying for the votes of disaffected arch conservatives. 
And the troubles for Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull could worsen should Queensland MP and Bernardi admirer George Christensen leave the LNP. 
If he did, he would take with him the Government’s House of Representatives one-seat majority. 
The instability could lead to an early election and certainly would apply greater pressure on Mr Turnbull’s leadership. 
Senator Bernardi — an Adelaide publican before becoming a financial adviser — was sent to the Upper House in 2006 to replace retiring Liberal moderate Robert Hill. 
He has formed a group called The Conservative Movement. It is not a registered political party but is said to have 50,000 members. 
There is a substantial constituency potentially available. A Newspoll today revealed Pauline Hanson’s One Nation had eight per cent of primary votes. This could be as much as 10 per cent given some phone supporters are shy about admitting it to pollsters. 
A rebel Bernardi party could attract discontented voters who have problems with Senator Hanson or her policies. 
His latest inspiration has been President Donald Trump. 
Senator Bernardi spent three months from September in New York as an observer at the United Nations for the Parliament. His job was to improve links with the UN, a body he has criticised as unelected and unaccountable. 
During his three months he became. Trump fanboi and spent a significant amount of time tweeting his support girl the then presidential candidate. 
As soon as he returned to Australia from the taxpayer-funded trip speculation began he would break from the Liberals. 
He is a social conservative on marriage, abortion and families. 
Senator Bernardi has not been on the Coalition front bench since 2012 when he quit as shadow parliamentary secretary for family support after arguing gay marriage could lead to approval of bestiality. Malcolm Turnbull has long had an uncomfortable relationship with Cory Bernardi, pictured here with Bruce Baird after the Press Gallery v Federal politicians swimming relay race at Parliament House pool in Canberra in 2007. Source: News Limited
